trans-unit.source: Creating a Windows Store leaderboard app with .NET Backend | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Creating a Windows Store leaderboard app with .NET Backend | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to build a Windows Store leaderboard app using Azure Mobile Services with a .NET backend.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to build a Windows Store leaderboard app using Azure Mobile Services with a .NET backend.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how build a Windows Store app using Azure Mobile Services with a .NET backend.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how build a Windows Store app using Azure Mobile Services with a .NET backend.

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services provides a scalable and secure backend with built-in authentication, monitoring, push notifications, and other features, plus a cross-platform client library for building mobile apps.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services provides a scalable and secure backend with built-in authentication, monitoring, push notifications, and other features, plus a cross-platform client library for building mobile apps.

trans-unit.source: The .NET backend for Mobile Services is based on <linkText>ASP.NET Web API</linkText><title></title>, and gives .NET developers a first-class way to create REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: The .NET backend for Mobile Services is based on <linkText>ASP.NET Web API</linkText><title></title>, and gives .NET developers a first-class way to create REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: Web API is an open-source framework that gives .NET developers a first-class way to create REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: Web API is an open-source framework that gives .NET developers a first-class way to create REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: You can host a Web API solution on Azure Websites, on Azure Mobile Services using the .NET backend, or even self-hosted in a custom process.
trans-unit.target: You can host a Web API solution on Azure Websites, on Azure Mobile Services using the .NET backend, or even self-hosted in a custom process.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services is a hosting environment that is designed especially for mobile apps.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services is a hosting environment that is designed especially for mobile apps.

trans-unit.source: When you host your Web API service on Mobile Services, you get the following advantages in addition to data storage:
trans-unit.target: When you host your Web API service on Mobile Services, you get the following advantages in addition to data storage:

trans-unit.source: Built-in authentication with social providers and Azure Active Directory (AAD).
trans-unit.target: Built-in authentication with social providers and Azure Active Directory (AAD).

trans-unit.source: Push notifications to apps using device-specific notification services.
trans-unit.target: Push notifications to apps using device-specific notification services.

trans-unit.source: A full set of client libraries that make it easy to access your service from any app.
trans-unit.target: A full set of client libraries that make it easy to access your service from any app.

trans-unit.source: Built-in logging and diagnostics.
trans-unit.target: Built-in logging and diagnostics.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you will:
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you will:

trans-unit.source: Create a REST API using Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Create a REST API using Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Publish the service to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Publish the service to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create a Windows Store app that consumes the service.
trans-unit.target: Create a Windows Store app that consumes the service.

trans-unit.source: Use Entity Framework (EF) to create foreign key relations and data transfer objects (DTOs).
trans-unit.target: Use Entity Framework (EF) to create foreign key relations and data transfer objects (DTOs).

trans-unit.source: Use ASP.NET Web API to define a custom API.
trans-unit.target: Use ASP.NET Web API to define a custom API.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses <linkText>Visual Studio 2013 latest update</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses <linkText>Visual Studio 2013 latest update</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A leaderboard shows a list of players for a game, along with their scores and the rank of each player.
trans-unit.target: A leaderboard shows a list of players for a game, along with their scores and the rank of each player.

trans-unit.source: A leaderboard might be part of a larger game, or could be a separate app.
trans-unit.target: A leaderboard might be part of a larger game, or could be a separate app.

trans-unit.source: A leaderboard is a real-world application, but is simple enough for a tutorial.
trans-unit.target: A leaderboard is a real-world application, but is simple enough for a tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Here is a screen shot of the app:
trans-unit.target: Here is a screen shot of the app:

trans-unit.source: To keep the app simple, there is no actual game.
trans-unit.target: To keep the app simple, there is no actual game.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you can add players and submit a score for each player.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you can add players and submit a score for each player.

trans-unit.source: When you submit a score, the mobile service calculates the new rankings.
trans-unit.target: When you submit a score, the mobile service calculates the new rankings.

trans-unit.source: On the back end, the mobile service creates a database with two tables:
trans-unit.target: On the back end, the mobile service creates a database with two tables:

trans-unit.source: Player.
trans-unit.target: Player.

trans-unit.source: Contains the player ID and name.
trans-unit.target: Contains the player ID and name.

trans-unit.source: PlayerRank.
trans-unit.target: PlayerRank.

trans-unit.source: Contains a player's score and rank.
trans-unit.target: Contains a player's score and rank.

trans-unit.source: PlayerRank has a foreign key to Player.
trans-unit.target: PlayerRank has a foreign key to Player.

trans-unit.source: Each player has zero or one PlayerRank.
trans-unit.target: Each player has zero or one PlayerRank.

trans-unit.source: In a real leaderboard app, PlayerRank might also have a game ID, so that a player could submit scores for more than one game.
trans-unit.target: In a real leaderboard app, PlayerRank might also have a game ID, so that a player could submit scores for more than one game.

trans-unit.source: The client app can perform the full set of CRUD operations on Players.
trans-unit.target: The client app can perform the full set of CRUD operations on Players.

trans-unit.source: It can read or delete existing PlayerRank entities, but it cannot create or update them directly.
trans-unit.target: It can read or delete existing PlayerRank entities, but it cannot create or update them directly.

trans-unit.source: That's because the rank value is calculated by the service.
trans-unit.target: That's because the rank value is calculated by the service.

trans-unit.source: Instead, the client submits a score, and the service updates the ranks for all players.
trans-unit.target: Instead, the client submits a score, and the service updates the ranks for all players.

trans-unit.source: Download the completed project <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Download the completed project <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Launch Visual Studio and create a new ASP.NET Web Application project.
trans-unit.target: Launch Visual Studio and create a new ASP.NET Web Application project.

trans-unit.source: Name the project Leaderboard.
trans-unit.target: Name the project Leaderboard.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2013, the ASP.NET Web Application project includes a template for Azure Mobile Service.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2013, the ASP.NET Web Application project includes a template for Azure Mobile Service.

trans-unit.source: Select this template and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select this template and click OK.

trans-unit.source: The project template includes an example controller and data object.
trans-unit.target: The project template includes an example controller and data object.

trans-unit.source: These aren't needed for the tutorial, so you can delete them from the project.
trans-unit.target: These aren't needed for the tutorial, so you can delete them from the project.

trans-unit.source: Also remove the references to TodoItem in WebApiConfig.cs and LeaderboardContext.cs.
trans-unit.target: Also remove the references to TodoItem in WebApiConfig.cs and LeaderboardContext.cs.

trans-unit.source: You will use <linkText>EF Code First</linkText><title></title> to define the database tables.
trans-unit.target: You will use <linkText>EF Code First</linkText><title></title> to define the database tables.

trans-unit.source: Under the DataObjects folder, add a class named Player.
trans-unit.target: Under the DataObjects folder, add a class named Player.

trans-unit.source: Add another class named PlayerRank.
trans-unit.target: Add another class named PlayerRank.

trans-unit.source: Notice that both classes inherit from the EntityData class.
trans-unit.target: Notice that both classes inherit from the EntityData class.

trans-unit.source: Deriving from EntityData makes it easy for the app consume the data, using the cross-platform client library for Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Deriving from EntityData makes it easy for the app consume the data, using the cross-platform client library for Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: EntityData also makes it easier for an app to handle database write conflicts.
trans-unit.target: EntityData also makes it easier for an app to handle database write conflicts.

trans-unit.source: The PlayerRank class has a navigation property that points to the related Player entity.
trans-unit.target: The PlayerRank class has a navigation property that points to the related Player entity.

trans-unit.source: The [ForeignKey] attribute tells EF that the Player property represents a foreign key.
trans-unit.target: The [ForeignKey] attribute tells EF that the Player property represents a foreign key.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will add Web API controllers for Player and PlayerRank.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will add Web API controllers for Player and PlayerRank.

trans-unit.source: Instead of plain Web API controllers, you will add a special kind of controller called a table controller, designed specifically for Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Instead of plain Web API controllers, you will add a special kind of controller called a table controller, designed specifically for Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Right click the Controllers folder > Add > New Scaffolded Item.
trans-unit.target: Right click the Controllers folder > Add > New Scaffolded Item.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Scaffold dialog, expand Common on the left and select Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Scaffold dialog, expand Common on the left and select Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Then select Azure Mobile Services Table Controller.
trans-unit.target: Then select Azure Mobile Services Table Controller.

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Controller dialog:
trans-unit.target: In the Add Controller dialog:

trans-unit.source: Under Model class, select Player.
trans-unit.target: Under Model class, select Player.

trans-unit.source: Under Data context class, select MobileServiceContext.
trans-unit.target: Under Data context class, select MobileServiceContext.

trans-unit.source: Name the controller "PlayerController".
trans-unit.target: Name the controller "PlayerController".

trans-unit.source: Click Add.
trans-unit.target: Click Add.

trans-unit.source: This step adds a file named PlayerController.cs to the project.
trans-unit.target: This step adds a file named PlayerController.cs to the project.

trans-unit.source: The controller derives from TableController. This class inherits ApiController, but is specialized for Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: The controller derives from TableController. This class inherits ApiController, but is specialized for Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Routing: The default route for a TableController is /tables/{table_name}/{id}, where table_name matches the entity name.
trans-unit.target: Routing: The default route for a TableController is /tables/{table_name}/{id}, where table_name matches the entity name.

trans-unit.source: So the route for the Player controller is /tables/player/{id}.
trans-unit.target: So the route for the Player controller is /tables/player/{id}.

trans-unit.source: This routing convention makes TableController consistent with the Mobile Services REST API.
trans-unit.target: This routing convention makes TableController consistent with the Mobile Services REST API.

trans-unit.source: Data access: For database operations, the TableController class uses the IDomainManager interface, which defines an abstraction for data access.
trans-unit.target: Data access: For database operations, the TableController class uses the IDomainManager interface, which defines an abstraction for data access.

trans-unit.source: The scaffolding uses EntityDomainManager, which is a concrete implementation of IDomainManager that wraps an EF context.
trans-unit.target: The scaffolding uses EntityDomainManager, which is a concrete implementation of IDomainManager that wraps an EF context.

trans-unit.source: Now add a second controller for PlayerRank entities.
trans-unit.target: Now add a second controller for PlayerRank entities.

trans-unit.source: Follow the same steps, but choose PlayerRank for the model class.
trans-unit.target: Follow the same steps, but choose PlayerRank for the model class.

trans-unit.source: Use the same data context class; don't create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Use the same data context class; don't create a new one.

trans-unit.source: Name the controller "PlayerRankController".
trans-unit.target: Name the controller "PlayerRankController".

trans-unit.source: Recall that PlayerRank has a related Player entity:
trans-unit.target: Recall that PlayerRank has a related Player entity:

trans-unit.source: The Mobile Service client library does not support navigation properties, and they will not be serialized.
trans-unit.target: The Mobile Service client library does not support navigation properties, and they will not be serialized.

trans-unit.source: For example, here is the raw HTTP response for GET /tables/PlayerRank:
trans-unit.target: For example, here is the raw HTTP response for GET /tables/PlayerRank:

trans-unit.source: Notice that Player is not included in the object graph.
trans-unit.target: Notice that Player is not included in the object graph.

trans-unit.source: To include the player, we can flatten the object graph by defining a data transfer object (DTO).
trans-unit.target: To include the player, we can flatten the object graph by defining a data transfer object (DTO).

trans-unit.source: A DTO is an object that defines how data is sent over the network.
trans-unit.target: A DTO is an object that defines how data is sent over the network.

trans-unit.source: DTOs are useful whenever you want the wire format to look different than your database model.
trans-unit.target: DTOs are useful whenever you want the wire format to look different than your database model.

trans-unit.source: To create a DTO for PlayerRank, add a new class named PlayerRankDto in the DataObjects folder.
trans-unit.target: To create a DTO for PlayerRank, add a new class named PlayerRankDto in the DataObjects folder.

trans-unit.source: In the PlayerRankController class, we'll use the LINQ Select method to convert PlayerRank instances to PlayerRankDto instances.
trans-unit.target: In the PlayerRankController class, we'll use the LINQ Select method to convert PlayerRank instances to PlayerRankDto instances.

trans-unit.source: Update the GetAllPlayerRank and GetPlayerRank controller methods as follows:
trans-unit.target: Update the GetAllPlayerRank and GetPlayerRank controller methods as follows:

trans-unit.source: With these changes, the two GET methods return PlayerRankDto objects to the client.
trans-unit.target: With these changes, the two GET methods return PlayerRankDto objects to the client.

trans-unit.source: The PlayerRankDto.PlayerName property is set to the player name.
trans-unit.target: The PlayerRankDto.PlayerName property is set to the player name.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example response after making this change:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example response after making this change:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the JSON payload now includes the player names.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the JSON payload now includes the player names.

trans-unit.source: Instead of using LINQ Select statements, another option is to use AutoMapper.
trans-unit.target: Instead of using LINQ Select statements, another option is to use AutoMapper.

trans-unit.source: This option requires some additional setup code, but enables automatic mapping from domain entities to DTOs.
trans-unit.target: This option requires some additional setup code, but enables automatic mapping from domain entities to DTOs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Mapping between Database Types and Client Types in the .NET Backend using AutoMapper</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Mapping between Database Types and Client Types in the .NET Backend using AutoMapper</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The PlayerRank entity includes a Rank property.
trans-unit.target: The PlayerRank entity includes a Rank property.

trans-unit.source: This value is calculated by the server, and we don't want clients setting it.
trans-unit.target: This value is calculated by the server, and we don't want clients setting it.

trans-unit.source: Instead, clients will use a custom API to submit a player's score.
trans-unit.target: Instead, clients will use a custom API to submit a player's score.

trans-unit.source: When the server gets a new score, it will update all of the player ranks.
trans-unit.target: When the server gets a new score, it will update all of the player ranks.

trans-unit.source: First, add a class named PlayerScore to the DataObjects folder.
trans-unit.target: First, add a class named PlayerScore to the DataObjects folder.

trans-unit.source: In the PlayerRankController class, move the MobileServiceContext variable from the constructor to a class variable:
trans-unit.target: In the PlayerRankController class, move the MobileServiceContext variable from the constructor to a class variable:

trans-unit.source: Delete the following methods from PlayerRankController:
trans-unit.target: Delete the following methods from PlayerRankController:

trans-unit.source: PatchPlayerRank
trans-unit.target: PatchPlayerRank

trans-unit.source: PostPlayerRank
trans-unit.target: PostPlayerRank

trans-unit.source: DeletePlayerRank
trans-unit.target: DeletePlayerRank

trans-unit.source: Then add the following code to PlayerRankController:
trans-unit.target: Then add the following code to PlayerRankController:

trans-unit.source: The PostPlayerScore method takes a PlayerScore instance as input.
trans-unit.target: The PostPlayerScore method takes a PlayerScore instance as input.

trans-unit.source: (The client will send the PlayerScore in an HTTP POST request.)
trans-unit.target: (The client will send the PlayerScore in an HTTP POST request.)

trans-unit.source: The method does the following:
trans-unit.target: The method does the following:

trans-unit.source: Adds a new PlayerRank for the player, if there isn't one in the database already.
trans-unit.target: Adds a new PlayerRank for the player, if there isn't one in the database already.

trans-unit.source: Updates the player's score.
trans-unit.target: Updates the player's score.

trans-unit.source: Run a SQL query that batch updates all of the player ranks.
trans-unit.target: Run a SQL query that batch updates all of the player ranks.

trans-unit.source: The [Route] attribute defines a custom route for this method:
trans-unit.target: The [Route] attribute defines a custom route for this method:

trans-unit.source: You could also put the method into a separate controller.
trans-unit.target: You could also put the method into a separate controller.

trans-unit.source: There is no particular advantage either way, it just depends how you want to organize your code.
trans-unit.target: There is no particular advantage either way, it just depends how you want to organize your code.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about the [Route] attribute, see Attribute Routing in Web API.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about the [Route] attribute, see Attribute Routing in Web API.

trans-unit.source: In this section, I'll describe the Windows Store app that consumes the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In this section, I'll describe the Windows Store app that consumes the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: However, I won't focus much on the XAML or the UI.
trans-unit.target: However, I won't focus much on the XAML or the UI.

trans-unit.source: Instead, I want to focus on the application logic.
trans-unit.target: Instead, I want to focus on the application logic.

trans-unit.source: You can download the complete project <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can download the complete project <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Add a new Windows Store App project to the solution.
trans-unit.target: Add a new Windows Store App project to the solution.

trans-unit.source: I used the Blank App (Windows) template.
trans-unit.target: I used the Blank App (Windows) template.

trans-unit.source: Use NuGet Package Manager to add the Mobile Services client library.
trans-unit.target: Use NuGet Package Manager to add the Mobile Services client library.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, from the Tools menu, select NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, from the Tools menu, select NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: Then select Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Then select Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: In the Package Manager Console window, type the following command.
trans-unit.target: In the Package Manager Console window, type the following command.

trans-unit.source: The -Project switch specifies which project to install the package to.
trans-unit.target: The -Project switch specifies which project to install the package to.

trans-unit.source: Create a folder named Models and add the following classes:
trans-unit.target: Create a folder named Models and add the following classes:

trans-unit.source: These classes correspond directly to the data entities in the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: These classes correspond directly to the data entities in the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) is a variant of Model-View-Controller (MVC).
trans-unit.target: Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) is a variant of Model-View-Controller (MVC).

trans-unit.source: The MVVM pattern helps separate application logic from presentation.
trans-unit.target: The MVVM pattern helps separate application logic from presentation.

trans-unit.source: The model represents the domain data (player, player rank, and player score).
trans-unit.target: The model represents the domain data (player, player rank, and player score).

trans-unit.source: The view model is an abstract representation of the view.
trans-unit.target: The view model is an abstract representation of the view.

trans-unit.source: The view displays the view model and sends user input to the view model.
trans-unit.target: The view displays the view model and sends user input to the view model.

trans-unit.source: For a Windows Store app, the view is defined in XAML.
trans-unit.target: For a Windows Store app, the view is defined in XAML.

trans-unit.source: Add a class named LeaderboardViewModel.
trans-unit.target: Add a class named LeaderboardViewModel.

trans-unit.source: Implement INotifyPropertyChanged on the view model, so the view model can participate in data binding.
trans-unit.target: Implement INotifyPropertyChanged on the view model, so the view model can participate in data binding.

trans-unit.source: Next, add observable properties.
trans-unit.target: Next, add observable properties.

trans-unit.source: The XAML will data bind to these properties.
trans-unit.target: The XAML will data bind to these properties.

trans-unit.source: The IsPending property is true while an async operation is pending on the service.
trans-unit.target: The IsPending property is true while an async operation is pending on the service.

trans-unit.source: The ErrorMessage property holds any error message from the service.
trans-unit.target: The ErrorMessage property holds any error message from the service.

trans-unit.source: Finally, add methods that call through to the service layer.
trans-unit.target: Finally, add methods that call through to the service layer.

trans-unit.source: Open the App.xaml.csfile and add a MobileServiceClient instance to the App class.
trans-unit.target: Open the App.xaml.csfile and add a MobileServiceClient instance to the App class.

trans-unit.source: When you debug locally, the mobile service runs on IIS express.
trans-unit.target: When you debug locally, the mobile service runs on IIS express.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio assigns a random port number, so the local URL is http://localhost:port, where port is the port number.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio assigns a random port number, so the local URL is http://localhost:port, where port is the port number.

trans-unit.source: To get the port number, start the service in Visual Studio by pressing F5 to debug.
trans-unit.target: To get the port number, start the service in Visual Studio by pressing F5 to debug.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will launch a browser and navigate to the service URL.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will launch a browser and navigate to the service URL.

trans-unit.source: You can also find the local URL in the project properties, under Web.
trans-unit.target: You can also find the local URL in the project properties, under Web.

trans-unit.source: In the main page, add an instance of the view model.
trans-unit.target: In the main page, add an instance of the view model.

trans-unit.source: Then set the view model as the DataContext for the page.
trans-unit.target: Then set the view model as the DataContext for the page.

trans-unit.source: As I mentioned earlier, I won't show all of the XAML for the app.
trans-unit.target: As I mentioned earlier, I won't show all of the XAML for the app.

trans-unit.source: One benefit of the MVVM pattern is to separate presentation from app logic, so it's easy to change the UI, if you don't like the sample app.
trans-unit.target: One benefit of the MVVM pattern is to separate presentation from app logic, so it's easy to change the UI, if you don't like the sample app.

trans-unit.source: The list of players is displayed in a ListBox:
trans-unit.target: The list of players is displayed in a ListBox:

trans-unit.source: Rankings are displayed in a ListView:
trans-unit.target: Rankings are displayed in a ListView:

trans-unit.source: All data binding happens through the view model.
trans-unit.target: All data binding happens through the view model.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will publish your mobile service to Microsoft Azure and modify the app to use the live service.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will publish your mobile service to Microsoft Azure and modify the app to use the live service.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Leaderboard project and select Publish.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the Leaderboard project and select Publish.

trans-unit.source: In the Publish dialog, click Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In the Publish dialog, click Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: If you are not signed into your Azure account already, click Sign In.
trans-unit.target: If you are not signed into your Azure account already, click Sign In.

trans-unit.source: Select an existing Mobile Service, or click New to create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Select an existing Mobile Service, or click New to create a new one.

trans-unit.source: Then click OK to publish.
trans-unit.target: Then click OK to publish.

trans-unit.source: The publishing process automatically creates the database.
trans-unit.target: The publishing process automatically creates the database.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to configure a connection string.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to configure a connection string.

trans-unit.source: Now you are ready to connect the leaderboard app to the live service.
trans-unit.target: Now you are ready to connect the leaderboard app to the live service.

trans-unit.source: You need two things:
trans-unit.target: You need two things:

trans-unit.source: The URL of the service
trans-unit.target: The URL of the service

trans-unit.source: The application key
trans-unit.target: The application key

trans-unit.source: You can get both from the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can get both from the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, click Mobile Services, and then click the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, click Mobile Services, and then click the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The service URL is listed on the dashboard tab.
trans-unit.target: The service URL is listed on the dashboard tab.

trans-unit.source: To get the application key, click Manage Keys.
trans-unit.target: To get the application key, click Manage Keys.

trans-unit.source: In the Manage Access Keys dialog, copy the value for the application key.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage Access Keys dialog, copy the value for the application key.

trans-unit.source: Pass the service URL and the application key to the MobileServiceClient constructor.
trans-unit.target: Pass the service URL and the application key to the MobileServiceClient constructor.

trans-unit.source: Now when you run the app, it communicates with the real service.
trans-unit.target: Now when you run the app, it communicates with the real service.

trans-unit.source: [Learn more about Azure Mobile Services]
trans-unit.target: [Learn more about Azure Mobile Services]

trans-unit.source: [Learn more about Web API]
trans-unit.target: [Learn more about Web API]

trans-unit.source: [Handle database write conflicts]
trans-unit.target: [Handle database write conflicts]

trans-unit.source: [Add push notifications]; for example, when someone adds a new player or updates a score.
trans-unit.target: [Add push notifications]; for example, when someone adds a new player or updates a score.

trans-unit.source: [Get started with authentication]
trans-unit.target: [Get started with authentication]

trans-unit.source: #overview
trans-unit.target: #overview

trans-unit.source: #about-the-sample-app
trans-unit.target: #about-the-sample-app

trans-unit.source: #create-the-project
trans-unit.target: #create-the-project

trans-unit.source: #add-data-models
trans-unit.target: #add-data-models

trans-unit.source: #add-web-api-controllers
trans-unit.target: #add-web-api-controllers

trans-unit.source: #use-a-dto-to-return-related-entities
